I looked at java.awt.robot.  Robot could drive the GUI.  However, 
I've use other robot like products (WinRunner) and found the test 
cases become very hard to maintain.  Problems arrise whenever widgets 
on the screen change position.  The Robot is still trying to perform 
mouse clicks and other actions on the old location.  Since GUI are 
gooey (i.e. change shape a lot while being developed), the testing 
script shouldn't depend on screen locations.

Instead, I think the best approach is using some tools that access 
the GUI components directly, no matter where they are placed on the 
screen.  This can test the functionality of the GUI.  A human will 
still have to perform "Usability" testing.

I hope to automate the more mundane and time consuming tasks of 
testing valid and invalid input, and checking the general function of 
the system.

- Greg
